titlestmt.subtitle: Papers of Joseph Bissonette, 1855-1862, at the Lilly Library, Indiana University
titlestmt.author: Electronic finding aid encoded by Indiana University Libraries.

did.abstract: The Bissonette mss., 1855-1862, consist of letters and documents primarily of Joseph Bissonette, trader and frontiersman, from Nebraska Territory, relating to claims for losses incurred from depredations committed by the Indians.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Many collections are housed offsite; retrieval requires advance notice. Please make an appointment a minimum of one week in advance of your visit.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Joseph Bissonette was born into a family of explorers in the French region of what is now East St. Louis, Illinois, on 26 May 1814. In the 1840s, he joined Colonel John C. Fremont's expeditions exploring the Rocky Mountains and was an interpreter for Chief Red Cloud. By the 1860s, he had moved to the Nebraska Territory, near Fort Laramie, where he worked as a trader. He eventually moved to the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation and died in Oglala Lakota County, South Dakota, in August 1894.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Bissonette mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Bissonette mss., 1855-1862, are letters and documents primarily of Joseph Bissonette, trader and frontiersman, from Nebraska Territory, relating to claims for losses incurred from depredations committed by the Indians.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Photography and digitization may be restricted for some collections. Copyright restrictions may apply. Before publishing, researchers are responsible for securing permission from all applicable rights holders, then filling out the Permission to Publish form.
